Greenish white petals 4 dry, 1 seeded little nuts enclosed in the persistent sepal. Spherical, wrinkled and brown. Not mucilaginous in water. -Calix closes when ready to seed The plant is indigenous to tropical areas e.g. West Africa It is cultivated in Ceylon, South Sea Islands, and also within Nepal, and Bengal Identified as Raam tulsi by South Asian communities surveyed in the UK. G30_768 ITS  trnH-psbA  277 Sukvinder Kaur Bhamra Image: Species: General Description: Description of Leaves: Description of Flowers: (Inflorescence) Description of Fruit: Native to: Any other information: DNA Sequence: Ocimum kilimandscharicum -Perennial -An evergreen -Shrubby -Very hairy -Grows larger then tenuiflorum -pubescent quadrangular branchlets with simple leaves that are opposite and oblong, narrow at the base and deeply serrated -Rounded leaves -Purple flowers -seeds are black and very small, -oval shaped -1mm East Africa Common names: Kilimanjaro basil, Camphor basil, Hoary basil, Fever plant G31_676 ITS  trnH-psbA  Ocimum tenuiflorum - Short-lived perennial herb. - Up to 1 m tall square stem -Green / purple -Elliptic (narrow oval) in shape -opposite decussate leaves, with numerous oil glands which secrete aromatic oils giving the plants distinct odours -smaller flowers than O. basilicum -white and yellow to purple -Flowers are more spread out -can see the stalk for each flower. Four small brown nutlets, which, unlike basil, do not produce a lot of mucilage when wet. dark brown odourless but pungent tasting seed South Asia Other species in the Ocimum genus which may be kept as tulsi include: O. ammericanum, O. basilicum, O. canum, O. camphora, O.kilimandscharicum and O. micranthum Identified as Shyam/ Krishna tulsi.
